 In the civilian accounting world the question of whether an entity is nearing insolvency is determined by definition of 'going concern'. The first step in that determination is an assessment of financial statement reliability and validity. Borrowing from the social security public trust for general operating expenses would put corporate officers and directors in the slammer, that's the equivalent of using 941 withholding taxes to pay operating expenses. That said, politicians have learned to easily manipulate the public.
 
 There are two generally accepted definitions of insolvency, liabilities exceeding assets or balance sheet insolvency, and inability to pay debts, equitable insolvency.
 
 Governments generally accept annual GDP as a country's assets and existing national debt as liabilities. Government accountants are prone to use double speak for the liability side, public debt, national debt, etc. (the political influence), but in the real world debt is debt. With a 2004 GDP of $11.4-trillion and national debt of $8-trillion, the US is not balance sheet insolvent. 
 Several countries are technically balance sheet insolvent, but in global economics equitable insolvency is the determining factor, can the country service its debt.
 
 The US is servicing our debt by expanding credit to make debt payments. In the business world creditors long ago would have forced us into bankruptcy reorganization, more likely dissolution to recover assets. The fact remains that we're important to the economies of other nations (not nearly as important as many would like to believe) and calling our debt is an impossibility as GDP can not be converted to tangible assets. So they make do with our bond interest and failing currency.
 
 Pretty basic scenario, as our creditworthiness deteriorates due to decreasing tax revenues and abnormal deficit spending, creditors demand higher interest rates to accept our debt. As monetary inflation through expanded debt decreases USD value, even higher interest rates are demanded to offset USD loses. The criterion for US solvency is how high can our interest rates go to service debt using available tax revenue and available debt without crashing the domestic, transaction oriented GDP. 
 
 We've stepped on our you know what. There's no easy fix, or any fix other than an eventual general economic depression as our leadership has maneuvered us into a corner. The only question is how long other countries will support our binge to maintain our impossibly high standard of living using personal and public debt, and that's dependent on how long our currency retains enough value to service debt that becomes more and more expensive. Government lingo is now focused on the elasticity of debt, using military aggression and global threats to drive GDP, but the simple fact exists that we're a debtor nation using a majority of the world's available natural resources with no hope of endless perpetuation of our circumstances. When is the only question of insolvency and the USD fate.

Personally, when I am looking at gold and silver, I am generally considering "currency of last resort". As such, I prefer to put it in my safe as opposed to buying it on paper (archaic, I know). Uranium has storage problems, like you need a really heavy safe and I am sure there is a permit process. I generally just play the currency market to protect against inflation. I have been told that there is a lot fo danger in that because if all the worlds currencies crash at once, you are screwed. In the real world, if all the worlds currency crashes at once, you are going to have one hell of a time getting whoever is holding your paper gold to redeem it anyway, so I figure 6 one half dozen the other.
 
 Personally, I llike god and silver because if you are buying physical product and it it either ungraded or below 99.9% pure, it is cheaper than dirt. I dabble in my lab with various methods of purifying/extracting pure gold or silver. One of my favorites is (simplified) to disolve the item in Hg, then boil the HG off (vacuum, not heat) and what you are left with is pure Silver, or gold. For my last experiment, I started with 70 oz of silver that I bought on Ebay. It was old chinese stuff of unknown purity. Total cost was $184. After putting it through my little refining process, I ended up with 61 OZ of pure silver. Market value=$688 minus a $15 fee to have it assayed.
 
 Not something that you are going to make a lot of money doing, but if you have the equipment (my equipment was left over from an electrohydrodynamic drive experiment I was working on), it is a cheap, and kind of fun way, to increase your emergency cash supply. It works with gold, too, but there is an additonal step involved. The up side of doing gold is that you can get nuggets for $20/oz, and often the profit margin on gold is higher.
 
 Take the finished product, toss it in your safe (mine is actually just stacked on a shelf in my lab) and you have a pretty comfortable cushion for a rainy day before long. 
 
 I always get mine assayed and stamped, but I have never sold any of it. It is more a hobby than anything else.
